item.title: TAMUCTF2019 Wordpress Write-up
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Hey guys! This post i‚Äôm my mindset on how I solved the Wordpress challenge from TAMUCTF2019

This kind of challenge is very similar to those HackTheBox challenges, where you have to get RCE from a system and then escalate your privileges to root! Let‚Äôs GO.

As I said before our goal is to get the flag inside ‚Äú/root/flag.txt‚Äù since it is inside the root folder we must become root to read it. (Most of the time) We‚Äôre given an openvpn config file to connect to that docker network where the machine is running.

Let‚Äôs start our enumaration with nmap.

And we get the following services.

Based on the nmap result, we got an ssh and HTTP Service. Cool, probably the WordPress site, so let‚Äôs focus on this.When we open the wordpress site, nothing calls our attention to explore so Iran WPScan against it.

This part cought my attention, apparently this wordpress is running ‚ÄúSlider Revolution‚Äù which seems to have a few exploits available. So I googled them a bit.

I found this modulo on metasploit that leads to RCE directly, I ran it but no so confident It would work.

But hey it did work and I got my reverse shell! Cool, part 1 finished.

Next step is to figure out how we can escalate our privileges to root. Let‚Äôs enumerate.

Without going very far I found an interesting file in /var/www called note.txt.

Hum? So the mysql database running for the wordpress, is not running in this server? Let‚Äôs find out where it is.

By going through the Wordpress config files we must check wp-config.php.

That‚Äôs interesting, we got DB_NAME, DB_USER, DB_PASSWORD and DB_HOST

At this time the challenge is basically over. Let‚Äôs connect to the mysql server.

We got our connection, so we‚Äôre inside the 172.30.0.2 where the backup ssh key is stored at /backup/id_rsa all we have to do now is read this file with mysql.

So i created a table foo inside Mysql database.

Then I loaded the content of the ssh key file inside the table.

I copied this private to my local computer and used to log via ssh.

And we got Root!

Hope you guys enjoyed it!

by me

item.title: TAMUCTF2019 PWN3 Write-up
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Hey Guys! This post i‚Äôll be showing you how I managed to solve PWN3 challenge from TAMUCTF2019! This was a standard stack execution where we had to insert our shellcode in the stack and point ou EIP there to execute it. Let‚ÄôGO!

Let‚Äôs execute the binary locally to see what happens.

After sending a lot of bytes we get a ‚Äúseg fault‚Äù and that‚Äôs what we want. Using GDB let‚Äôs find out how many bytes we must send to control EIP.

Using pattern_search we discover that offset is 302 bytes long. Cool valuable information there, but where is our ESP? Since that value keeps changing when we connect via netcat ASLR is on, so it gets hard to know where to point to. So we need to discover what is the address that pops up when the program is executed.

Running a few times in different environments I noticed that we can use this address to determine the exact position of our ESP, because that address + 0x132 = $ESP

Cool! Now we have everything set, let‚Äôs create our exploit.

Got my shellcode from shellstorm.com

Hope you guys enjoyed it!

by me

item.title: TAMUCTF2019 Onboarding Checklist Write-up
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Hey guys, This is how I solved the Onboading Checklist Challenge from TamuCTF 2019.

This kind of challenge you don‚Äôt see everyday so it was a lot of fun and really simple.

Let‚Äôs GO!

The Challenge presents itself with this message. Apparently ‚Äúimportantperson‚Äù has allowed ‚Äúsomeguy‚Äù to ask for new account request for the new employees and asked ‚Äúsomeguy‚Äù to send an e-mail to tamuctf@gmail.com with the new employee‚Äôs e-mail address. So, all we have to do is send a spoofed email to tamuctf@gmail pretending to ‚Äúsomeguy‚Äù with our e-mail address.

I used this Website to do it.

And a few hours later we get our response back.

Hope you guys enjoyed it!

by me

item.title: TAMUCTF2019 Keygenme ‚Äî Write-up
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Hello everybody! This is how I solved one of the many reversing problems at TAMUCTF 2019.

This one was Keygenme, a pretty standard kind of challenge but yet very fun to solve it.

Let‚Äôs go!

Let‚Äôs start by running the binary that was given to us and see what it says.

Basically, when we run the binary it asks for a product key and if we give an incorrect one it simply shuts itself down. Then I searched for the strings inside the binary, sometimes they help us understand what the program is doing.

By using rabin2 I was able to identify all the strings in the binary, all of them are very important so let‚Äôs take a look at them one by one

A pretty odd string that at the start don‚Äôt get our attention as the others, but it‚Äôs gonna be important in a moment.

That‚Äôs the string we just saw.

A string that everybody likes to see, but I don‚Äôt have a flag.txt? Do you?

String, even if we bypassed the checking functions using the disassembler locally we would not be able to retrieve our flag because it‚Äôs been hosted remotely.

So with this quick overview of the strings, we now know that we have to create our own keygen to beat this challenge.

Analyzing the binary with hopper disassembler there are 3 functions that get our attention

It‚Äôs pretty clear what each function is doing so I‚Äôm gonna skip that whole explanation and focus on the verify_key function first.

That part is at the beginning of the function verify_key and its job is to get our input, our ‚ÄúKEY‚Äù, and checks if its size is bigger than 0x9 in hexa aka 9 in decimal xd.

So, important information, we must supply a key that is longer than 9 digits, noted.

Right after this block, there‚Äôs a check to see if our input is larger than 0x40 bytes, since we will no be providing a key this long, I‚Äôm gonna skip it.

There are a few import things we must consider on this part of the function.

  1. The enc function is called by verify_key and not by main.
  2. Right after enc function is called our modified key is compared to [OIonU2_<__nK<KsK

Now it‚Äôs clear that we have to provide some input that after it passes the enc function it has to be equal to that strange string we saw early on.

Now we have to go through the enc function and figure what it is doing with our input and reverse it.

using this part and the hopper pseudo code:

I managed to write this whole process in python and I noticed that the next key‚Äôs value always depends on its previous neighbor. So to discover what key generates this [OIonU2_<__nK<KsK, I simply brute forced it XD.

LINK BASE GITHUB

By running this script I got

Let‚Äôs send to the server and get our FLAG!

Well‚Ä¶Maybe not üò¢.

Let‚Äôs use gdb-PEDA to find out why we did not get our deserved flag.

I set up a breakpoint right before my input and that awful string are compared and I got this.

So the program adds this ‚Äú\n‚Äù and I‚Äôm not sure why.

That thing made me wonder for a while why that‚Äôs there and how to bypass it.

Then I found the solution to be very simple (and a bit of luck maybe?). This ‚Äú\n‚Äù is changing into ‚Äúi‚Äù because it‚Äôs after a ‚ÄúB‚Äù, so I have to find a character that change ‚Äú\n‚Äù into ‚ÄúK‚Äù.

And the ‚ÄúR‚Äù was there all along to save me.

Hope you guys enjoyed it!

by me

item.title: TAMUCTF2019 Hello World Write-up
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Hey guys! This post I‚Äôll be showing you how I solved the Hello World Challenge from TAMUCTF2019.

This was a MISC challenge rated as medium difficulty by the CTF organizers.

I downloaded the file and used the cat command on it.

It showed something like that. That made me think, what are those blank spaces?

Using the xxd command and the hexadecimal of this file was shown.

Those strange ‚Äò20‚Äô and ‚Äò09‚Äô and ‚Äò0a‚Äô gotta mean something. After analyzing for a couple of minutes I noticed that the ‚Äò0a‚Äô repeats itself always after 10 spaces.

So I imagined this should be a binary encoded string where ‚Äò20‚Äô = 0 , ‚Äò09‚Äô = 1 and ‚Äò0a‚Äô = space. So I wrote a small python script to extract the flag!

LINK BASE GITHUB

Hope you guys enjoyed it!

by me

item.title: HACKAFLAG CAMPINAS Reverse & Misc Write-up
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Fala galera! at√© o dia 17/04 rolou a 1¬™ etapa do Hackaflag 2019.Consegui a 4¬™ coloca√ß√£o nesse etapa e os desafios foram bem legais.

Resolvi trazer esses dois porque foram os que achei mais divertidos de resolver.

PS: Esses foram os m√©todos que usei para resolver, talvez n√£o os melhores, mas com certeza cheguei nas flags xd

1 Desafio -> MISC

Descri√ß√£o: Por mais pequeno que seja, esse desafio vem com a miss√£o de fazer voc√™ conhecer um formato de arquivo EPS e entender como ele √© composto.

Al√©m dessa breve descri√ß√£o nos √© dado um arquivo para download. Vamos analis√°-lo.

Bem como disse a descri√ß√£o, temos um arquivo EPS, mas ainda n√£o conseguimos abri-lo porque no pr√≥prio retorno do comando file ele nos diz que o EPS come√ßa no byte 30.

Precisamos remover esses 30 primeiros bytes. Vamos usar o comando ‚Äòdd‚Äô para isso.

Agora quando rodamos o comando ‚Äòfile‚Äô novamente j√° nos √© retornado outra coisa

Vamos tentar abr√≠-lo com o programa Inkscape

Erro, pois ainda no arquivo h√° um tiff como vimos la no primeiro ‚Äòfile‚Äô que demos.

Para retir√°-lo, vamos usar o comando ‚Äòtruncate‚Äô

Agora ao abr√≠-lo com o Inkscape, temos

Essa imagem.

Essa parte √© sem d√∫vida a pior do desafio, achar onde diabos est√° a flag aqui.Passei horas, cheguei a pensar que a flag n√£o estivesse na imagem de tanto procurar, mas ela est√° ai. Uma parte da defini√ß√£o de uma EPS file diz isso:

It is more like a postscript program that instructs images and drawings to be placed on a document

Ent√£o pesquisei em formas de manipular essas imagens presentes e uma delas me ajudou, o XML Editor.

At√© que

Ta a√≠ a coisa.

Pegando todos os chars temos:

O que n√£o √© a flag final, mas √© f√°cil ver que a flag fica‚Ä¶

2 desafio -> REVERSE

Desafio mais complicado dessa primeira etapa, foi o que teve menos solves. Por assumir coisas erradas demorei muito mais tempo do que precisava para resolver esse desafio, mas no fim deu tudo certo.

Descri√ß√£o: Consegue me ajudar?

Al√©m da descri√ß√£o nos √© dado um bin√°rio, campinas.exe. Um bin√°rio windows, vamos execut√°-lo.

De cara j√° temos nossa flag em b64 somente - , sqn xd

Joguei o bin√°rio no Ghidra para ver do que se tratava.

Analisando as fun√ß√µes vemos uma bem interessante, Criptografar.

Mas est√° muito complicado de analis√°-la assim, fui atr√°s de ver as strings para ver se encontrava alguma luz.

Analisando notei essa que dizia ‚Äú.NET framework 4.6.1‚Äù e eu sei que consigo usar decompiler nesses sistemas, no caso usei o dotPeek da JetBrains e consegui o c√≥digo descompilado da fun√ß√£o Criptografar.

Analisando passo a passo do c√≥digo

  • Primeiro √© feito uma requisi√ß√£o para essa string em hexa mas em uma formata√ß√£o estranha, depois √© passado outros par√¢metros como m√©todo, ContentType, etc, quem n√£o nos interessa.
  • Depois ele pega o conte√∫do recebido do servidor e joga no MD5cryptoServiceProvider, ou seja, gera um md5 do retorno.
  • Ap√≥s isso, √© criado um TripleDESCryptoServiceProvider que tem como um dos par√¢metros a chave, que √© a hash md5 que foi gerado a pouco.
  • Ao final retorna a flag em base64 como vimos ao rodar o programa.

Nossa primeira e mais dif√≠cil tarefa ser√° descobrir o endere√ßo dessa requisi√ß√£o para conseguir nossa chave.

Vemos que a string encodada passada est√° em servindo de par√¢metro para outra fun√ß√£o, vamos analis√°-la, a class8_metho0, no meu caso.

No caso a class8_method0 s√≥ faz uma checagem de data e retorna a string para a class9_method0

Fiz uma pequena altera√ß√£o no c√≥digo e rodei a fun√ß√£o passando a string e o inteiro que vi na fun√ß√£o Criptografa.

E me √© retornado isso:

wtf is isso?

Notei que eu estava esperando uma url e resolvi comparar, notemos que podemos fazer ascii(x) ‚Äî 16 -> h ascii(d) +16 -> t ascii(`)-> p ascii(c) + 16-> s da√≠ ja conseguimos o ‚Äòhttps‚Äô

Eu realmente espero do fundo do cora√ß√£o que haja um m√©todo melhor de resolver do que esse T.T Ao terminarmos de decodar:

https://hackaflag.com.br/ctf/desafios/1ad8fd2dfbb0adc015d7b35a42bb9b89/commandcontrol.php

Acessando esse link encontramos nossa chave.

Depois disso devemos lembrar que a chave foi encodada em b64 para fazer criptografar nossa flag.

Ent√£o,

  • Criptografia TripleDES
  • Modo ECB
  • chave = d5637a2c7e17f17947df72f5b3d3d20c
  • flag = YMP1zrjTmr1P0wVJh7ocL55O5ZY3EYec

J√° temos tudo!

Usei essa √≥tima ferramenta online para conseguir a flag.

CLICK TO ACCESS 3DES Encryption

Tive que passar a flag para hex, pois a tool n√£o suportava b64.

Assim foi como resolvi essas duas flags dessa etapa, espero que algu√©m tenha aprendido algo, se n√£o escrevi isso tudo pra nada xd

Obrigado!

By me

item.title: Frolic ‚Äî HacktheBox Walkthrough
item.description:
Tags: CTF | RATF | FLAG | CHALLENGE

Hey guys! In this post I will be showing how I solved the machine ‚ÄúFrolic‚Äù from HackTheBox.

It was a pretty ctf like machine, and well‚Ä¶ I love ctfs, so that turned out to be really fun, specially priv esc part.

I‚Äôll be posting the links where I got some references on how to proceed when I got a bit stucked.

Let‚Äôs start with our standard nmap scan:

We can spot four different services running on this box, three of them are useless for us, so let‚Äôs focus on the service running on port 9999, a web service.

We are presented with the default nginx page, brute forcing some directories we find the /admin page.

A log in page, we must find some credentials. Looking in the source code of the js file, we find this.

Great, we got our user and pass. Let‚Äôs check the success.html page.

What the heck is this?? üòê

After some searching on esoteric languages I found this ‚ÄúOok!?‚Äù Programming language and a website that could decode it.

It tells us to check another directory so off we go.

Reaching this dir we find this

It appears to be a base64 encoded message, so when I decoded it show a PK‚Ä¶ among other random bytes.So this is a zip file.

When I tried the unzip It asks for a password. I just brute forced it and the password found as was ‚Äúpassword‚Äù, how cool xd.

Moving on, the file inside called ‚Äúindex.php‚Äù shows:

obviously some hex code

decoding it we get another b64 and after that we find this

That‚Äôs clearly a brain f*ck code. Let‚Äôs see what is says

Cool, we got something that looks like a password, but password for what? üòø

Let‚Äôs go back to our enumeration phase and start over, we must have missed something.

Awesome, after some more enumeration we got nothing xd

Let‚Äôs keep trying

Looking into dev/ folder we have another backup.

And there we have a /playsms folder, finally something to use ours creds on.

To get our reverse shell I found this great exploit on github.

CLICK TO ACCESS GITHUB- jasperla

Sweet! We got rce.

Since this is a pretty bad shell I got a new one using php and netcat. But I‚Äôll just skip this part xd

After getting a better shell, just went to the user home dir and found user.txt xd.

Now the root part!

Searching the home directory of ayush, we find a .binary dir.

We find a ‚Äúrop‚Äù binary. Notice its permissions, any user can execute it and do it as root because the sticky bit is set.So if we invoke a shell using this binary we get root, let‚Äôs try.

In this post I‚Äôll not be explaining how a buffer overflow occurs or how to exploit it in details. I‚Äôm just gonna explain some thoughts that I had during the exploitation.

The binary simply runs with an argument the we pass and spits it back out for us, nothing interesting, however if we send a lot of bytes to it, it breaks.

Cool, we can overwrite EIP but return where?

The name of the binary already gives us a pretty good hint on what to do, let‚Äôs use a technique called ‚ÄúReturn to libc‚Äù that is a type of ROP.

You can learn more what is ROP here

If you wanna know more about Ret2libc those following links helped me a lot.

CLICK TO ACCESS RET2LIBC

So basically we need 5 things to succeed.

  1. The offset to overwrite EIP
  2. libc base address
  3. system call offset
  4. exit call offset (optional)
  5. string ‚Äú/bin/bash‚Äù

Lets do one by one:

To get the offset to overwrite eip I used that pretty standard technique with pattern_create, and got a number of 52.

To get libc base address we use ldd and grep for libc.

Note: ASLR is turned off in this box, so lucky for us we don‚Äôt need to bypass it.

Now we need system call offset for libc we do

Same thing for exit function.

Now the last thing we need is to find ‚Äú/bin/sh‚Äù string, we do.

Sweet, we got everything we need. Let‚Äôs chain all together with some python code.

So running this:

we get our root shell!

Hope you guys enjoyed it!

by me
